item.title: Black Ops 6 player count: How many people are playing?
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/black-ops-6-player-count-how-many-people-are-playing/

Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 brings the iconic FPS franchise back to the forefront, offering players a brand new Campaign, Multiplayer, and Zombies mode to enjoy.

Treyarch has focused on bringing Call of Duty back to its roots, which has enticed both veteran and new players. With a traditional Prestige system, a new arsenal of weapons to unlock, and a variety of maps and modes to enjoy, players have been flocking to Multiplayer. Those who love the round-based format of Zombies have been satisfied too, while story enjoyers are getting their fix through the Campaign.

That said, how many are actually paying Black Ops 6 and what does the player count look like? Here’s everything you need to know.

How many players are in Black Ops 6?

Unfortunately, there are no official stats for the Black Ops 6 player count, but according to SteamDB, there are 143,030 current Steam OC players on Call of Duty as of October 28, 2024.

The 24 hour peak sits at 306,460 players, but keep in mind this is only the player count for Steam on PC, so if you take console into account too, the figure is likely much higher than this. Call of Duty is extremely popular on Xbox and PlayStation, and so those platforms likely make up a large portion of the player count which isn’t available to the public.

The Call of Duty HQ app also includes players on COD games such as MW3, MW2, and Warzone. It even takes those playing the Campaign and Zombies into account, so it’s not an accurate number for those playing the Multiplayer.

Black Ops 6 is also the first Call of Duty title to release on the Game Pass for both PC and Xbox consoles. Because of this, there a likely a lot of PC players enjoying BO6 via the Game Pass, and the SteamDB numbers don’t track that platform. Thanks to the Game Pass release, successful beta period, and hype prior to release, we expect Black Ops 6’s number to be very healthy, pointing to a successful launch.

There also haven’t been many server issues or major bugs, so players have been able to grind. Once we know official numbers we’l be sure to update this piece with all the information. However, Call of Duty haven’t released official player count stats for some time now, so it’s unclear whether we will get any insight.

If you’re looking to earn Scorestreaks with ease and reach a high rank quickly, be sure to sign up to the Insider Gaming newsletter, where you’ll receive all the latest BO6 news and tips.

item.title: SAG-AFTRA Strike With Video Game Voice And Performance Artists To Continue
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/sag-aftra-strike-with-video-game-voice-and-performance-artists-to-continue/

SAG-AFTRA has announced that its strike against video game studios will continue. The announcement comes after more negotiations between the parties over AI protections and better general working conditions failed to result in a deal..

“After three days of scheduled negotiations, SAG-AFTRA announced that Interactive Media Agreement negotiations with employers would continue, with new dates to be announced as soon as they are confirmed,” the union said in a statement.

“Negotiations resumed with the employer unit which includes Activision Productions Inc., Blindlight LLC, Disney Character Voices Inc., Electronic Arts Productions Inc., Formosa Interactive LLC, Insomniac Games Inc., Llama Productions LLC, Take 2 Productions Inc., and WB Games Inc. on Oct. 23.”

The union says that the strike remains in place against “all signatories to the Interactive Media Agreeement”. The only exception is to games “signed to the Tiered-Budget Independent Interactive Media Agreement or an Interim Interactive Media Agreement.”

The latest video game strike began in July when SAG-AFTRA called for it after 18 months of negotiations between the union and various game studios. The union believes that studios don’t have their actors’ best interests in mind when it comes to potential AI exploitation.

“We’re not going to consent to a contract that allows companies to abuse A.I. to the detriment of our members. Enough is enough. When these companies get serious about offering an agreement our members can live — and work — with, we will be here, ready to negotiate,” SAG-AFTRA President Fran Drescher said at the beginning of the strike.

What do you think about the latest video game strike, and its call for protections against AI for voice and performance actors? Let us know down below, or in the official Insider Gaming forums.

For more Insider Gaming, check out our full review of Call of Duty: Black Ops 6. And don’t forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.
